description: wall hanging; openwork weaving in thick strands of tan and brown; vertical wood element at top center; central vertical strip below wood element in green-grey and brown; shorter vertical elements with twisted tassels in brown, green, grey and tan; thick brown fringe at bottom
text:
Maria Laszkiewicz was an innovator in bringing the practices of tapestry and sculpture into
dialogue. She and the other weavers who worked in her Warsaw atelier in the 1950s and
1960s also experimented with nontraditional weaving materials, particularly wood and sisal,
a fiber derived from rope.
In Mask, the woven ground is composed of a traditional Gobelin weave, which situates the
work in the French tapestry tradition. But the frequent incorporation of vertical slits, which
accentuate the geometric color patterning, is reminiscent of Precolumbian tapestries. This
design choice, in combination with the central carved wooden mask which gestures to
African art, reveals Laszkiewicz’s interest in non-European textile and sculpture traditions.
title: Mask
